content.description: <math alttext="2 A gas plus B gas is in equilibrium with 2 C gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>A</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>â‡„</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: <math alttext="A gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> react to form <math alttext="C gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, according to the balanced equation above. In an experiment, a previously evacuated rigid vessel is charged with <math alttext="A gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, each with a concentration of <math alttext="0.0100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The following table shows the concentrations of the gases at equilibrium at a particular temperature.<math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[C]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.01800.01400.0020If the experiment is repeated at a higher temperature at which <math alttext="K sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is larger, which of the following best describes the effect of the temperature change on the concentrations of the gases at equilibrium?

choices.label: <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[C]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> will all increase because <math alttext="K sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increased.

<math alttext=" the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> will remain constant, but <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>C]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> will increase because <math alttext="K sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increased.

There will be a decrease in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that will be two times the decrease in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> react in a 2-to-1 ratio.

There will be an increase in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that will be two times the increase in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> react in a 2-to-1 ratio.

content.answer: There will be a decrease in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[A]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that will be two times the decrease in <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[B]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> react in a 2-to-1 ratio.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
